thread.title_full: Digital and Physical Collage Techniques Create Hallucinatory Neon Pop Art

author: Masha (Maria) Koblyakova
title: Digital and Physical Collage Techniques Create Hallucinatory Neon Pop Art
text:
Digital and Physical Collage Techniques Create Hallucinatory Neon Pop Art Nick Thomm mixes mediums into an iridescent psychedelic palette. 
Vibrant kaleidoscopic mixed-media meets the visual cues of modern pop culture , bringing digital and physical dimensions together to highlight the shrinking gap between them in the work of Nick Thomm . The Australian artist creates hallucinatory neon collages, makes holographic skateboards, and hyper-colors immersive projection environments. 
Considering the contemporary era as "a time when a major new art medium has been introduced," Thomm aims to create works that make the digital world more physical. Exploring how much aesthetic control he can have over machines, Thomm makes his works tactile. Different mediums, materials, and printing techniques make his works attractive in the way that your retina display is. "Part of the work always looks like it should be stuck inside a screen, but then it's blended with traditional mediums that make it feel unusually 'real' to the viewer," Thomm explains. Lucky Cat 
As for the aesthetics, Thomm explores ideas of subconscious and surrealism. "I want everything to feel hypnotic, like a dream that you can't control," he says. The dream begins at the point when a viewer sees a familiar imagery in new combinations like the maneki-neko cat or the fragments of glossy fashion photographs floating amongst psychedelic colors. Paris 
One of the inspirations for Thomm's pop-culture pastiches is an understanding that his bold and bright designs "will exist far longer" that he does. He hopes that this work will help to picture the way our generation experienced the chemistry between art and technology in the hyper-connected society. Ghost 2016
